item.title: India's Christians Attacked Under Anti-Conversion Laws
Putin Blames the West for Talk of ‘War, War, War’
item.description: At a traditional year-end news conference, in comments intended to sway a domestic audience, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said his country was defending historically Russian territories.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Yuri Kochetkov/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia held his traditional year-end news conference on Thursday.

item.title: Of Mouth Molds and Michelin Stars: Chef Finds Fame After Epic Takedown
item.description: Panned by a prominent blogger, the Italian restaurant Bros’ and its celebrity chef became a global target for critics of pretentious cuisine. There was a good side for him.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Serving the final dish of a 13-course tasting menu that left a blogger complaining,“there was nothing even close to an actual meal served.”

item.title: Fury in China After Li Tiantian, an Outspoken Teacher, Disappears
item.description: Supporters of Li Tiantian believe that local officials may have sent her to a psychiatric hospital, a longstanding way of stifling and discrediting dissent.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: ‘Koala Massacre’: Australia Files Hundreds of Animal Cruelty Charges
item.description: A property owner and two companies in Australia were charged after a land-clearing operation left dozens of the marsupials dead, injured or starving.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Victoria Conservation Regulator
item.media:description: A koala that was brought to a rehabilitation center after its habitat was destroyed in the Australian state of Victoria. Dozens of others died.

item.title: Covid Spoils Another Christmas in the Holy Land
item.description: Israel’s strict border controls have largely barred foreign tourists from entry, but the traditional Jerusalem Santa is managing to bring some local cheer.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Issa Kassissieh, the traditional Santa Claus of the Holy Land, entertaining a few visitors in his workshop this week.

item.title: Covid Live Updates: European Nations Add Restrictions as Cases Surge
item.description: Greece will require masks in all outdoor and indoor public spaces, including gyms. The Chinese authorities lock down Xi’an, a city of 13 million. And China sets out elaborate precautions for February’s Winter Olympics.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Kevin Frayer/Getty Images

item.title: U.K. System Strained as Health Care Workers Get Covid Themselves
item.description: Hospitals, clinics and ambulance services say infections are winnowing their staffs, straining a system already taxed by nearly two years of dealing with the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Tolga Akmen/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Outside the Royal London Hospital on Monday. The latest wave of coronavirus cases is putting severe pressure on Britain’s health care system.

item.title: How China's CATL Became the Top Electric Car Battery Maker
item.description: Beijing gave CATL lavish subsidies, a captive market of buyers and soft regulatory treatment, helping it to control a crucial technology of the future.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher and Michael Forsythe
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: CATL’s headquarters, shaped like an oversize lithium battery, in Ningde, China.

item.title: Hong Kong Removes 'Pillar of Shame' Statue Amid Crackdown
item.description: The decision to take down the “Pillar of Shame,” an enduring symbol of the territory’s pro-democracy movement, was another sign of Beijing’s crackdown.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Hong Kong Alliance in Support of Patriotic Democratic Movements of China
item.media:credit: Anthony Kwan/Getty Images
item.media:description: Workers removing part of the “Pillar of Shame” statue at the University of Hong Kong on Thursday.

item.title: Covid’s Risk to Older Adults
item.description: Ready to give up on the pandemic? Spare a moment to think about older people.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Janice Chung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Passing out home test kits in New York City yesterday.

item.title: Omicron-Driven Pushes for Boosters Could Prolong Pandemic, W.H.O. Says
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah
item.media:credit: Denis Balibouse/Reuters
item.media:description: Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, the W.H.O.’s director-general, warned on Wednesday that booster programs in highly vaccinated nations could take resources away from largely unvaccinated ones.

item.title: How to Catch a Polar Bear
item.description: First, spot the bear.
item.dc:creator: Anna Filipova and Emily Anthes
item.media:credit: Anna Filipova for The New York Times

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Encouraging data on Omicron.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Jane Barlow/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A vaccination line in Edinburgh this week.

item.title: Omicron Infections Seem to Be Milder, Three Research Teams Report
item.description: The data offer a rare bit of good news. Still, hospitalizations are likely to increase simply because the variant is so contagious.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer and Emily Anthes
item.media:credit: John Taggart for The New York Times
item.media:description: Covid-19 testing from a van in Manhattan on Tuesday. Experts warn that Americans should take rapid tests before holiday events and should gather outside, open windows or find other ways to improve ventilation.

item.title: Three Dead and Many Missing as Migrant Boat Sinks Near Greece
item.description: The sinking came just weeks after 27 people drowned trying to cross the English Channel, another stark reminder of the lethal risks facing asylum seekers.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Aegean Sea, where the Greece Coast Guard rescued 12 survivors from a smuggler boat in distress.

item.title: Studies Find Omicron May Be Less Severe Than Delta
item.description: U.K. studies found fewer hospitalizations compared to Delta.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Victoria Jones/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Medical staff tended to patients in a Covid ward at King's College Hospital, in London on Tuesday.

item.title: California Requires Health Workers to Get Boosters by Feb. 1
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom said more than half of the sequenced cases in the state have been identified as the Omicron variant, but the real number is probably higher.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Mario Tama/Getty Images
item.media:description: A coronavirus test being administered in the international terminal at Los Angeles International Airport on Tuesday.

item.title: CityMD Temporarily Shuts 19 Locations Amid Urgent Testing Demands
item.description: The closures began on Wednesday, and CityMD has not said how long they will last.
item.dc:creator: Precious Fondren
item.category: City Practice Group of New York (CityMD)
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Waiting in line for a Covid-19 test at a CityMD clinic in Washington Heights.

item.title: What would it cost to end the pandemic?
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden takes questions from reporters after delivering remarks on Covid-19 in the State Dining Room of the White House in Washington on Tuesday.

item.title: Reimposed travel restrictions spoil another Christmas season in the Holy Land.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Ahmad Gharabli/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem, built on the traditional site of Jesus’ birth, will see few Christian pilgrims this year because of pandemic travel restrictions imposed by Israel.

item.title: As Humanitarian Disaster Looms, U.S. Opens Door for More Afghanistan Aid
item.description: The Treasury Department and the United Nations offered new protection for aid from sanctions meant to pressure the Taliban.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sacks of flour from a World Food Program convoy were unloaded in Afghanistan in October. The Treasury Department will make it easier for international organizations and the U.S. government to provide relief to Afghans while maintaining economic pressure on the Taliban.

item.title: Turkey issues emergency-use authorization for its domestically produced vaccine.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Esra Hacioglu/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A health worker in Ankara, Turkey, prepares to administer a booster dose of the country’s Turkovac vaccine to a volunteer in a clinical trial.

item.title: Americans are tired, and Omicron is just beginning.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei
item.media:credit: Ariana Drehsler for The New York Times
item.media:description: A diner in San Diego on Monday.

item.title: Much maligned during the pandemic, caroling is back. Outside London pubs, that is.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Tom Jamieson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Carol singers outside the Mayflower pub in London last week. Live singing has been among the most demonized of cultural activities since the pandemic, since it has been linked to superspreader events.

item.title: ‘The Daily’: A Covid testing crisis, again.
item.media:credit: Ted S. Warren/Associated Press
item.media:description: Boxes of BinaxNow home Covid-19 tests made by Abbott Laboratories on sale in November at a CVS store in Lakewood, Wash.

item.title: Decoding Joe Manchin
item.description: The senator’s history suggested he could vote for Build Back Better. Why didn’t he?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Joe Manchin at a Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources hearing.

item.title: Holiday traveling and Omicron: Here are some strategies for staying safe.
item.dc:creator: Heather Murphy
item.media:credit: Carlo Allegri/Reuters
item.media:description: Experts advise getting tested as close to the day of a gathering as possible.

item.title: Singapore and Malaysia freeze ticket sales for vaccinated travel amid Omicron fears.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon and Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Mohd Rasfan/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A passenger at Kuala Lumpur International Airport in Malaysia before flying to Singapore last month.

item.title: Inflation Forces Parisian Vendors to Raise Prices on Staples
item.description: Soaring inflation in Europe is starting to squeeze shopkeepers and consumers. Many are preparing for more price increases in the new year.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Florian Bocciarelli, right, a third-generation butcher in Paris. Meat prices are up 10 percent since the summer.

item.title: Using a City’s Excess Heat to Reduce Emissions
item.description: A district in London has developed an innovative way to divert subway heat for buildings to lower carbon emissions. Other cities are getting creative, as well.
item.dc:creator: Tatiana Schlossberg
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Old Street station in the London Underground.

item.title: A Tense Libya Delays Its Presidential Election
item.description: The postponement risks further destabilizing the oil-rich North African country, which has been mired in divisions and violence in the decade since Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi was toppled and killed in a revolution.
item.dc:creator: Mona El-Naggar and Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Mahmud Turkia/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Nearly 100 candidates had declared they were running in Libya’s presidential election.

item.title: Dozens Feared Dead After Landslide at Jade Mine in Myanmar
item.description: An official said one person was killed after more than 70 were swept into a lake by mining waste in Hpakant, the center of the country’s secretive jade industry.
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Rescuers preparing to search after a landslide Wednesday left more than 70 people missing at a jade mine in northern Myanmar.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: President Biden’s plan to combat Omicron.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times

item.title: Israel to Administer 4th Round of Covid Vaccines
item.description: Israel is believed to be the first country to roll out fourth doses.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Ahmad Gharabli/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Israel is at the beginning of a fifth wave of infections.

item.title: Holiday travel in the U.S. is expected to jump, even as Omicron spreads.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:credit: Joe Raedle/Getty Images
item.media:description: A security checkpoint last month at Miami International Airport.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Omicron Restrictions
item.description: China aims for zero-Covid, while other nations take softer approaches.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Amit Dave/Reuters
item.media:description: Jabuben Bharwad, 30, received a dose of the Covishield coronavirus vaccine while working in a field during a vaccination drive outside Ahmedabad, India.

item.title: Libya’s Long-Awaited Election Will Most Likely Be Delayed
item.description: A postponement raises the possibility that the oil-rich North African nation could again descend into the fragmentation and violence that have marked the decade since its dictator was toppled.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Mahmud Turkia/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A billboard in the Libyan capital, Tripoli, encouraging citizens to vote. “Your participation is the future of your country.”

item.title: 2 Ship Officers Plead Guilty to Light Charges in Mauritius Oil Spill
item.description: The leak was an environmental calamity for the Indian Ocean nation, which relies on its beaches and lagoons for tourism and fishing.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Gwendoline Defente/Etat Major des Armees, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Fuel leaking from the MV Wakashio a few weeks after it ran aground on a coral reef off the coast of Mauritius in July 2020.

item.title: Who Is Gabriel Boric, Chile's Next President?
item.description: Mr. Boric, 35, is now the most prominent face of a generation of Chileans who are calling for a break with the past.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz, Pascale Bonnefoy and John Bartlett
item.media:credit: Martin Bernetti/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Gabriel Boric, president-elect of Chile, celebrating his election in Santiago on Sunday.

item.title: These Carol Singers Are Carrying on, Despite Omicron Variant
item.description: Last year, most carol singing in Britain was canceled because of the pandemic. This year, a group of roving singers was determined to carry on, despite the Omicron variant.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Tom Jamieson for The New York Times

item.title: Here’s what we know about Biden’s speech on the U.S. Omicron response.
item.description: The president is expected to announce several new steps, including setting up new testing and vaccination sites, deploying federal vaccinators and buying 500 million rapid tests to distribute free.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden returning to the White House on Monday after spending the weekend in Wilmington, Del. He is expected to announce new steps to confront the national surge in coronavirus cases.

item.title: British Court Orders Dubai Ruler to Pay £554 Million in Custody Settlement
item.description: The settlement, of about $734 million, resolves a lengthy dispute that began when Princess Haya Bint Al Hussein and her two children fled to London in 2019.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:credit: Luke Macgregor/Reuters
item.media:description: Princess Haya Bint Al Hussein, in England in 2010 with her husband at the time, Dubai’s ruler, Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid al-Maktoum.

item.title: At Bagram Air Base, a Notorious Prison Lies Empty
item.description: Taliban fighters now guard the prison at Bagram Air Base, which once held thousands of Taliban and Al Qaeda members who were set free in August.
item.dc:creator: David Guttenfelder and David Zucchino
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Taliban fighter stands on top of the outer security wall surrounding former US military Bagram Airfield, this month.

item.title: India's Modi Brings Tap Water to Millions as Supplies Shrink
item.description: The ambitious project to meet a dire need shows Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s strengths and helps explain his popularity despite a weakened economy.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal, Hari Kumar and Saumya Khandelwal
item.media:description: Water scarcity in Imlidol, a village in the central Indian state of Madhya Pradesh, means people grow only one crop a year.

item.title: Cashing In Grandma’s Gold Coins, a Turkish Family Struggles to Get By
item.description: As inflation soars and the value of Turkey’s currency plummets, one couple described how working families can’t make ends meet and have had to cut back on basic necessities as well as life’s smaller pleasures.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Men fished from the Galata Bridge in Istanbul. In the last three months, the Turkish currency has lost nearly half its value against the dollar and inflation has soared.

item.title: France Uncovers Over 180,000 Fake Covid Passes
item.description: The developments suggest that resistance to Europe’s vaccination requirements remains significant.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Sarah Meyssonnier/Reuters
item.media:description: A demonstration against Covid-19 vaccination passes in Paris on Saturday.

item.title: Areas Where the U.S. Has Fallen Behind on Omicron
item.description: The U.S. is behind on the variant. President Biden offers his plan today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Spencer Platt/Getty Images
item.media:description: A line for testing yesterday in Times Square.

item.title: New Zealand and Other Asia Pacific Countries Respond to Omicron
item.description: New Zealand is taking measures to limit the spread of Omicron, including delaying the reopening of its borders. It has detected 22 cases of Omicron in international arrivals.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost and Livia Albeck-Ripka
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Fiona Goodall/Getty Images
item.media:description: Officials at a checkpoint for people leaving the Auckland area in New Zealand last week.

item.title: How the Kremlin Is Militarizing Russian Society
item.description: With a “youth army,” a cathedral honoring the military and state media promoting patriotism, the government is preparing Russians for the possibility of a fight.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Ivan Nechepurenko, Valerie Hopkins and Sergey Ponomarev
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: An award ceremony for a patriotic club in Vladimir, Russia.

item.title: Lawmakers Urge Big Tech and Justice Dept. to Act on Suicide Site
item.description: A House committee sought briefings from search engines whose services might have been leveraged by the site, which has been linked to numerous deaths. Seven House members asked the Justice Department about avenues for investigation.
item.dc:creator: Gabriel J.X. Dance and Megan Twohey
item.category: House Committee on Energy and Commerce
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Richard Blumenthal, Democrat of Connecticut, wrote in a letter to Google that the company had the ability and legal authority to steer “people who are struggling away from this dangerous website.”

item.title: A Wall Street Banker Turned to Comedy for Happiness and a Career Change
item.description: Shaun Eli Breidbart was a banker on Wall Street for 19 years but he gave up a lucrative career in favor of happiness.
item.dc:creator: Pierre-Antoine Louis
item.media:credit: Nate Palmer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shaun Eli Breidbart at the Broadway Comedy Club in New York, where he has performed frequently.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Another Covid Christmas.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Peter Dejong/Associated Press
item.media:description: A normally bustling shopping street in the center of Amsterdam was mostly quiet on Monday. Due to a nationwide lockdown, all non-essential stores, bars and restaurants in the Netherlands will be closed until Jan. 14.

item.title: Deal With Ted Cruz Sets Stage for Russia Pipeline Fight in Early 2022
item.description: The Texas Republican leveraged his obstruction of diplomatic nominees into a Senate vote that could complicate President Biden’s efforts to defend Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Sarahbeth Maney/The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Ted Cruz agreed not to obstruct the routine confirmation of 36 of Mr. Biden’s State Department and Treasury Department nominees after a vote was set for January to sanction the Nord Stream 2 pipeline.
